message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Human-in-the-Loop Consensus Tracking Control for UAV Systems via an Improved Prescribed Performance Approach
Paper Abstract: In some crucial consensus tracking missions, the sign of the tracking error is not allowed to change during the tracking process. The existing tracking control schemes are unable to satisfy this requirement. To solve this issue, this work improves the conventional prescribed performance control (PPC) approach and applies it to the cooperative control of unmanned aircraft vehicle (UAV) systems. Moreover, the flight controller design incorporates human decision-making. This hybrid active interaction approach implies that humans and UAVs can execute complex and variable flight missions as a collaborative team. Considering that equipped motors are prone to faults when operating in harsh environments, this article presents an adaptive fuzzy fault compensation mechanism to ensure the flight safety of UAVs. Finally, the simulation study validates the effectiveness and control advantage of the proposed approach.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, "consensus control" most likely refers to two related concepts:

## Consensus Dynamics and Control

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory.(no content)It studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange, which is known as the consensus problem in multi-agent systems.(no content)The consensus protocol, or agreement protocol, defines the rules of interaction that lead to convergence.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## Related Concepts

Related coordination problems include the rendezvous problem, synchronization, flocking, and formation control, which often rely on similar mathematical foundations and are studied under the broader umbrella of cooperative control.

The concept is also relevant in computer science, where the consensus problem is a fundamental problem in controlling multi-agent systems.

I found comprehensive information about unmanned aerial vehicles. Here's an overview:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

## Modern Development

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made, with its affordability, accessibility, and user-friendly software quickly capturing the consumer drone market.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These include aircraft maintenance, surveillance, search and rescue, crop spraying, infrastructure inspection, and disaster response.

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about adaptive control:

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## How It Differs from Robust Control

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Types of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

## Recent Developments

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.

Based on the search results, here's information about adaptive control:

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## How It Differs from Robust Control

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Types of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

## Recent Developments

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.

Links: [{"title":"Human-in-the-loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-in-the-loop"},{"title":"Humans in the Loop (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humans_in_the_Loop_(film)"},{"title":"Reciprocal human machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_human_machine_learning"},{"title":"User-in-the-loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-in-the-loop"},{"title":"Hardware-in-the-loop simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardware-in-the-loop_simulation"},{"title":"Human–computer interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–computer_interaction"},{"title":"Human performance modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_performance_modeling"},{"title":"Looped (TV series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Looped_(TV_series)"},{"title":"Ring (novel series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_(novel_series)"},{"title":"Humanistic intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanistic_intelligence"}]

## Human-in-the-Loop: Overview

Human-in-the-loop (HITL) is used in multiple contexts and can be defined as a model requiring human interaction. This concept is fundamental across various technical and simulation applications.

### Key Characteristics

Human-in-the-loop allows the user to change the outcome of an event or process.(no content)Although much can be done to automate systems, humans typically still need to take the information provided by a system to determine the next course of action based on their judgment and experience.

### Applications and Benefits

HITL is associated with modeling and simulation (M&S) in the live, virtual, and constructive taxonomy. Some practical applications include:

- **Training and Skill Transfer**: This can be demonstrated by trainees utilizing flight simulators in preparation to become pilots.

- **Process Evaluation**: A real-world example of HITL simulation as an evaluation tool is its usage by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to allow air traffic controllers to test new automation procedures by directing the activities of simulated air traffic while monitoring the effect of the newly implemented procedures.

- **Problem Discovery**: HITL simulations bring to the surface issues that would not otherwise be apparent until after a new process has been deployed.

### Related Concepts

Reciprocal human machine learning (RHML) aims to enable continual learning between humans and machine learning models by having them learn from each other, keeping the human expert "in the loop" to oversee and enhance machine learning performance and simultaneously support the human expert continue learning.

Based on the search results, here's information about control theory:

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability; often with the aim to achieve a degree of optimality.

## How Control Systems Work

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

## Fault Tolerance - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about fault tolerance. Here's an overview of the key concepts:

### Definition and Purpose

Fault tolerance is the ability of a system to maintain proper operation despite failures or faults in one or more of its components.(no content)This capability is essential for high-availability, mission-critical, or even life-critical systems.(no content)Fault tolerance specifically refers to a system's capability to handle faults without any degradation or downtime.

### Key Characteristics

In the event of an error, end-users remain unaware of any issues. This differs from resilience, where a system that experiences errors with some interruption in service or graceful degradation of performance is termed 'resilient', and in resilience, the system adapts to the error, maintaining service but acknowledging a certain impact on performance.

### Approaches and Techniques

Common fault tolerance methods include:

- **Redundancy**: Hardware fault tolerance sometimes requires that broken parts be removed and replaced with new parts while the system is still operational (in computing known as hot swapping).

- **Software Fault Tolerance**: Design patterns such as retry, fallback, timeout, circuit breaker, and bulkhead pattern should be combined to make the system more fault tolerant.

- **Byzantine Fault Tolerance**: The objective of Byzantine fault tolerance is to be able to defend against failures of system components with or without symptoms that prevent other components of the system from reaching an agreement among themselves.

### Historical Development

The first known fault-tolerant computer was SAPO, built in 1951 in Czechoslovakia by Antonín Svoboda, and its basic design was magnetic drums connected via relays, with a voting method of memory error detection (triple modular redundancy).

## Fuzzy Control

Based on the search results, here's what I found about fuzzy control:

### Definition

A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values.

### How It Works

Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.(no content)The process of converting a crisp input value to a fuzzy value is called "fuzzification".

### Historical Development

Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations that demonstrated the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway. Their ideas were adopted, and fuzzy systems were used to control accelerating, braking, and stopping when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

### Real-World Applications

Fuzzy control has been widely implemented in consumer and industrial products:

- Matsushita vacuum cleaners use microcontrollers running fuzzy algorithms to interrogate dust sensors and adjust suction power accordingly.
- Hitachi washing machines use fuzzy controllers to load-weight, fabric-mix, and dirt sensors and automatically set the wash cycle for the best use of power, water, and detergent.
- The 1000 series Sendai Subway trains were the world's first train type to use fuzzy logic to control its speed, and this system is 10% more energy efficient than human-controlled acceleration.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"); relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes); entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other; wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/); relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**
The paper proposes improvements to prescribed performance control for UAV systems with human-in-the-loop capabilities and adaptive fuzzy fault compensation. I extracted 7 core entities:

| Entity | Type | Relation | Purpose |
|--------|------|----------|---------|
| Unmanned aerial vehicle | Task | Uses | Primary system being controlled |
| Consensus dynamics | Concept | Uses | Enables multi-UAV agreement on tracking objectives |
| Control theory | Concept | Uses | Mathematical foundation for control design |
| Fuzzy control system | Method | **Proposes** | Novel adaptive fault compensation mechanism |
| Human-in-the-loop | Concept | **Proposes** | Novel hybrid human-UAV collaboration approach |
| Fault tolerance | Concept | Uses | Ensures flight safety during motor faults |
| Adaptive control | Method | Uses | Adjusts parameters in response to changing conditions |

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED

All triples have been properly formatted with:
- Correct Wikipedia article titles
- Valid entity types and relations
- Proper Wikipedia URLs
- Clear relevance statements

The file `triples_output.json` is now ready for use.

Sources:
- [Unmanned aerial vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle)
- [Consensus dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Fuzzy control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_control_system)
- [Human-in-the-loop](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-in-the-loop)
- [Fault tolerance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
